info.headline: Fire Weather Watch issued August 16 at 3:04AM PDT until August 17 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Medford
info.description: ...ISOLATED TO SCATTERED THUNDERSTORMS EXPECTED THIS WEEK... ...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM THURSDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH THURSDAY EVENING FOR FOR ABUNDANT LIGHTNING ON DRY FUELS... The National Weather Service in Medford has issued a Fire Weather Watch, which is in effect from Thursday afternoon through Thursday evening. * IMPACTS...Any fires that develop have a high probability of spreading rapidly. Abundant lightning can also ignite new fires and strain fire fighting resources. * AFFECTED AREAS...In Oregon...eastern portions of Fire weather zone 617...eastern and southeastern portions of Fire weather zone 622 and Fire weather zone 625. This includes portions of the Umpqua National Forest, foothill areas in eastern Jackson County and near Ashland, and BLM land in eastern Lake County. * THUNDERSTORMS...Isolated showers and thunderstorms are expected today through Thursday morning. Then, the potential increases for thunderstorms with a mix of isolated to scattered thunderstorms expected Thursday afternoon and evening. Storms will be a hybrid of wet/dry today, then trend wetter on Thursday, but lightning strikes outside of the wet cores are still likely. * OUTFLOW WINDS...Gusts 30 to 40 mph. * DETAILED URL...View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
info.instruction: If you have not packed your evacuation kit yet, now is the time to do so. This includes items like important documents and essentials you cannot live without. Fill your vehicle`s fuel tank. Visit ready.gov/kit for more information. Plan now to avoid using equipment that could cause sparks during the period when critical weather conditions are possible. Visit weather.gov/medford/wildfire for links to fire restrictions in your area. A Fire Weather Watch means that critical fire weather conditions are possible during the valid watch time. These conditions could promote the rapid spread of wildfires which could become life- threatening. Check weather.gov/medford for forecast updates and a possible upgrade of the this watch to a Red Flag Warning.
